drupalNodeEvent.title: Reading Nationally and Transnationally in the PRC

field_speakers.processed: Nicolai Volland (Penn State University), Matthew Wills (UC San Diego), Lena Henningsen (as discussant, University of Freiburg)

field_organizers.processed: European Research Council, University of Freiburg, ReadChina Team

field_description.processed: The intertwined state of the national and the transnational is a noteworthy issue in (the study of) reading practices. On the one hand, reading can be facilitated by the state and in turn help sustain the national image. On the other hand, reading in a certain national or local space often conceals (and reveals) transnational elements. In this final session of the ReadChina virtual lecture series both aspects of reading practices will be at the center. First, Nicolai Volland (Penn State University) will propose the model of a literary universe to address the transnational elements within Chinese literary space, as well as the interaction and interplay between its various elements. The second speaker, Matthew Wills (UC San Diego), will disclose how the state media in the PRC fashioned an image of the “reading nation” and fueled the demand for books during the “Criticize Lin, Criticize Confucius” campaign.
